anns.prefix: Before the discovery of natural antibiotics, synthetic compounds, including
anns.postfix: , sulfa drugs and quinolones, were in use as chemotherapeutic agents (Aminov, 2010).

was the first natural antibiotic to be discovered accidentally by Alexander Fleming in 1928 when the Penicillium fungus contaminated a culture plate in his laboratory, however, penicillin was not developed for use until the late 1930s (Hopwood, 2007).

anns.prefix: Penicillin was the first natural antibiotic to be discovered accidentally by Alexander Fleming in 1928 when the Penicillium fungus contaminated a culture plate in his laboratory, however,
anns.postfix: was not developed for use until the late 1930s (Hopwood, 2007).

inhibits cell wall synthesis and was found to be very effective against Gram-positive but not against Gram-negative bacteria (due to the presence of the outer membrane) or the tubercle bacillus (because of the extra thick cell wall) (Hopwood, 2007).

anns.prefix: Following the discovery of
anns.postfix: by Fleming, other scientists, including Rene Dubos and Selman Waksman, started a deliberate search for antibacterial agents among soil microorganisms, including bacteria and fungi.

anns.prefix: The next biggest discovery came about in 1943, resulting in identification of
anns.postfix: produced by Streptomyces griseus.

inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 30S subunit of the prokaryotic ribosome and was found to be effective not only against Gram-negative bacteria but also against the tubercle bacillus (Hopwood, 2007).

anns.prefix: With the discovery of
anns.postfix: , the golden age of antibiotic discovery and development (1940–1990) ensued.

anns.prefix: In producers of the
anns.postfix: family of antibiotics, the primary mechanism of resistance involves sequestration of the metal-bound or the metal-free antibiotic (Sugiyama and Kumagai, 2002) by binding proteins TlmA, BlmA, and ZbmA in S. hindustanus ATCC 31158 (Gatignol et al., 1988), S. verticillus (Sugiyama et al., 1994, 1995), and Streptomyces flavoviridis, respectively (Rudolf et al., 2015).

anns.prefix: Each

anns.prefix: Other examples of producers containing several mechanisms for self-resistance include the following: Microbispora ATCC PTA-5024 contains both an efflux pump (MlbJYZ) and a sequestration protein (MlbQ) to protect against
anns.postfix: (Pozzi et al., 2016); S. rimosus has an ABC multi-drug efflux pump (OtrC) (Yu et al., 2012) and an MFS pump (OtrB) for efflux of oxytetracycline (Mak et al., 2014) along with OtrA to protect the ribosome by antibiotic removal (Doyle et al., 1991); S. fradiae contains several gene products (TlrA, TlrB, and TlrD) that modify the ribosome to prevent tylosin binding and uses TlrC for efflux (Mak et al., 2014); and S. chattanoogensis L10 contains several different efflux pumps for resistance against natamycin (Wang et al., 2017).

anns.prefix: Other examples of producers containing several mechanisms for self-resistance include the following: Microbispora ATCC PTA-5024 contains both an efflux pump (MlbJYZ) and a sequestration protein (
anns.postfix: ) to protect against NAI-107 (Pozzi et al., 2016); S. rimosus has an ABC multi-drug efflux pump (OtrC) (Yu et al., 2012) and an MFS pump (OtrB) for efflux of oxytetracycline (Mak et al., 2014) along with OtrA to protect the ribosome by antibiotic removal (Doyle et al., 1991); S. fradiae contains several gene products (TlrA, TlrB, and TlrD) that modify the ribosome to prevent tylosin binding and uses TlrC for efflux (Mak et al., 2014); and S. chattanoogensis L10 contains several different efflux pumps for resistance against natamycin (Wang et al., 2017).

anns.postfix: genes are not confined to the clinic; instead they are widely prevalent in different bacterial populations in the environment.

anns.prefix: Therefore, to understand development of
anns.postfix: in pathogens, we need to consider important reservoirs of resistance genes, which may include determinants that confer self-resistance in antibiotic producing soil bacteria and genes encoding intrinsic resistance mechanisms present in all or most non-producer environmental bacteria.

anns.prefix: Therefore, to understand development of

anns.prefix: While the presence of
anns.postfix: determinants in soil and environmental bacteria does not pose a threat to human health, their mobilization to new hosts and their expression under different contexts, for example their transfer to plasmids and integrons in pathogenic bacteria, can translate into a problem of huge proportions, as discussed in this review.

anns.prefix: Thus, there is an urgent need to understand distribution of
anns.postfix: determinants in bacterial populations, elucidate resistance mechanisms, and determine environmental factors that promote their dissemination.

anns.prefix: This comprehensive review describes the major known
anns.postfix: mechanisms found in producer soil bacteria of the genus Streptomyces and explores the relationships between resistance determinants found in producer soil bacteria, non-producer environmental bacteria, and clinical isolates.

anns.prefix: Overall, this article provides a conceptual framework for understanding the complexity of the problem of emergence of

anns.prefix: Availability of such knowledge will allow researchers to build models for dissemination of
anns.postfix: genes and for developing interventions to prevent recruitment of additional or novel genes into pathogens.

anns.prefix: Introduction: A Brief Historical Perspective Introduction: A Brief Historical Perspective Selman Waksman, a prominent researcher in the field of actinomycetes in the early part of the twentieth century, described the term
anns.postfix: as a chemical compound generated from microorganisms that inhibits or destroys other microbes (Hopwood, 2007; Davies and Davies, 2010).

anns.prefix: Most
anns.postfix: in use today originated from the phylum Actinobacteria with nearly 80% of actinobacterial-derived antibiotics produced by soil-dwelling bacteria of the genus Streptomyces (Barka et al., 2016).

anns.prefix: Before the discovery of natural
anns.postfix: , synthetic compounds, including salvarsan, sulfa drugs and quinolones, were in use as chemotherapeutic agents (Aminov, 2010).

anns.prefix: Before the discovery of natural antibiotics, synthetic compounds, including salvarsan, sulfa drugs and quinolones, were in use as
anns.postfix: agents (Aminov, 2010).

anns.prefix: Penicillin was the first natural
anns.postfix: to be discovered accidentally by Alexander Fleming in 1928 when the Penicillium fungus contaminated a culture plate in his laboratory, however, penicillin was not developed for use until the late 1930s (Hopwood, 2007).

anns.prefix: Following the discovery of penicillin by Fleming, other scientists, including Rene Dubos and Selman Waksman, started a deliberate search for
anns.postfix: agents among soil microorganisms, including bacteria and fungi.

anns.prefix: It was soon realized that
anns.postfix: activity was most often present in actinomycete cultures and less often in other bacteria or fungi.

anns.prefix: During this period, several
anns.postfix: were discovered in the screens designed by these scientists but many of these were of little use in the clinic due to their toxicity in animals.

Modification or Degradation Antibiotic Modification or Degradation Antibiotic Modification or Degradation Antibiotic modification is a commonly used strategy for rendering an antibiotic ineffective, especially in the case of aminoglycoside antibiotics (for example, kanamycin, gentamycin, and streptomycin), chloramphenicol, and β-lactams.

anns.prefix: Multiplicity of Resistance Mechanisms in Producer Organisms Multiplicity of Resistance Mechanisms in Producer Organisms Most producer organisms contain several mechanisms for
For example, S. peucetius relies on DrrAB to efflux doxorubicin (Li et al., 2014; Brown et al., 2017), DrrC to remove the
anns.postfix: from its target DNA (Prija and Prasad, 2017), and DrrD is possibly used to modify the antibiotic to an inactive form (Karuppasamy et al., 2015).

anns.prefix: Other examples of producers containing several mechanisms for
anns.postfix: include the following: Microbispora ATCC PTA-5024 contains both an efflux pump (MlbJYZ) and a sequestration protein (MlbQ) to protect against NAI-107 (Pozzi et al., 2016); S. rimosus has an ABC multi-drug efflux pump (OtrC) (Yu et al., 2012) and an MFS pump (OtrB) for efflux of oxytetracycline (Mak et al., 2014) along with OtrA to protect the ribosome by antibiotic removal (Doyle et al., 1991); S. fradiae contains several gene products (TlrA, TlrB, and TlrD) that modify the ribosome to prevent tylosin binding and uses TlrC for efflux (Mak et al., 2014); and S. chattanoogensis L10 contains several different efflux pumps for resistance against natamycin (Wang et al., 2017).

anns.postfix: in Clinical Isolates Mechanisms of Antibiotic Resistance in Clinical Isolates Intrinsic vs. Acquired Resistance Intrinsic vs. Acquired Resistance Intrinsic vs. Acquired Resistance Intrinsic antibiotic mechanisms are normally chromosome-encoded and include non-specific efflux pumps (which likely evolved as a general response to environmental toxins), antibiotic inactivating enzymes, or mechanisms that serve as permeability barriers (Fajardo et al., 2008; Cox and Wright, 2013).

anns.prefix: A well-studied example of an intrinsic
anns.postfix: system is the AcrAB/TolC efflux pump in Escherichia coli, which has a very broad substrate specificity and can export different classes of antibiotics, dyes, detergents, and disinfectants (Nikaido and Takatsuka, 2009).

anns.prefix: Vancomycin
anns.postfix: in E. coli and other Gram-negative bacteria provides another example of intrinsic resistance, which results from the permeability barrier imposed by the outer membrane (Arthur and Courvalin, 1993).

anns.prefix: Although intrinsic mechanisms confer low level

anns.prefix: However, the distribution, expression, and genetic context of
anns.postfix: determinants in clinical strains are strikingly different.

anns.prefix: For example,

anns.prefix: The acquired
anns.postfix: efflux determinants, often found on MGEs in clinical isolates, are exemplified by many different types of tet genes (at least 22 have been identified) located on plasmids in both Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria (Roberts, 2005).

anns.prefix: Interestingly, RND pumps can act synergistically with the simple Tet pump proteins (MFS family), resulting in a significant increase in the minimum

anns.prefix: FIGURE 2Schematic showing reservoirs of
anns.postfix: genes found in nature and various pathways for their movement to the clinic.

anns.prefix: Transfer of
anns.postfix: genes to clinical isolates could occur by a variety of routes (shown by arrows), each using horizontal gene transfer mechanisms potentially involving plasmids, integrons, or transposons.

anns.prefix: While direct transfer of
anns.postfix: determinants from producers in the soil to clinical strains is possible (Route 1), a more likely route may first involve movement from the producer soil bacteria to non-producer soil bacteria (for example Mycobacterium species) (Pang et al., 1994) (Route 2A), followed by transfer to clinical pathogens through several carriers (Route 2B).

anns.prefix: Routes 2 and 3 are shown as thick red arrows, implying greater probability of these pathways for dissemination of
anns.postfix: genes to clinical strains.

anns.prefix: Indeed,
anns.postfix: genes are much more widespread in environmental non-pathogenic microbial populations than was originally believed (D’Costa et al., 2006; Nesme et al., 2014; Surette and Wright, 2017).

anns.prefix: In an interesting study, which tested 500 Streptomyces strains enriched and isolated from soil against 21

anns.prefix: The genome sequence analyses carried out in recent years have also shown that not only are the intrinsic
anns.postfix: mechanisms widely prevalent in all microbes (Fajardo et al., 2008; Cox and Wright, 2013), but that homologs of the resistance determinants of clinical isolates are commonly present in non-pathogenic Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria (Seoane and Garcia Lobo, 2000; Mukhtar et al., 2001; Sugantino and Roderick, 2002).

anns.prefix: Finally, there is also strong evidence showing that the
anns.postfix: gene sequences are ancient and predate the use of antibiotics (D’Costa et al., 2011; Bhullar et al., 2012; Warinner et al., 2014; Perron et al., 2015; Kashuba et al., 2017).

anns.prefix: Analysis of microbial DNA isolated from the dental plaque of ancient human remains showed the existence of gene sequences homologous to those conferring
anns.postfix: to β-lactams, aminoglycosides, macrolides, tetracycline, and bacitracin in clinical strains (Warinner et al., 2014; Olaitan and Rolain, 2016).

anns.prefix: Interestingly, the vanHAX cluster in permafrost DNA exhibited the same invariant organization as seen in modern vancomycin resistant isolates, confirming that these genes predate the use of
Other similar studies showing prevalence of
anns.postfix: determinants in ancient samples, or isolated caves, are also available (Bhullar et al., 2012; Perron et al., 2015; Kashuba et al., 2017).

anns.prefix: Together these findings suggest that there is a continuum of
anns.postfix: genes present in the environmental, producer, and pathogenic organisms, leading to the concept of ‘resistome’ which is described as the collection of antibiotic resistance genes found in all microorganisms (Wright, 2007).

anns.prefix: Role of HGT in Transfer of
anns.postfix: Genes Role of HGT in Transfer of Antibiotic Resistance Genes Transfer of antibiotic resistance determinants between bacterial populations occurs by genetic exchange mechanisms involving transformation with free DNA, transduction by bacteriophages, or conjugation involving plasmids (Wright, 2007; Hu et al., 2017), collectively referred to as the HGT mechanisms.

anns.prefix: Role of HGT in Transfer of Antibiotic Resistance Genes Role of HGT in Transfer of Antibiotic Resistance Genes Transfer of
anns.postfix: determinants between bacterial populations occurs by genetic exchange mechanisms involving transformation with free DNA, transduction by bacteriophages, or conjugation involving plasmids (Wright, 2007; Hu et al., 2017), collectively referred to as the HGT mechanisms.

anns.prefix: Indeed, transformation seems to have played an important role in evolution of
anns.postfix: strains of Streptococcus and Neisseria.

anns.prefix: For example, it is thought that the persistence of penicillin
anns.postfix: in S. pneumoniae may be related to the high frequency of natural transformation in this organism (Hoffman-Roberts et al., 2005).

anns.prefix: Transformation of Neisseria gonorrhoeae with DNA from resistant commensal Neisseria flavescens is believed to have resulted in generation of a mosaic penA variant that confers
anns.postfix: to β-lactams in clinical isolates (Spratt, 1988; Spratt et al., 1992).

anns.prefix: Mosaic variants of
anns.postfix: genes have also been reported in several Streptococcus species, implying the role of transformation in incorporating sections of foreign DNA (von Wintersdorff et al., 2016).

anns.prefix: Although these enzymes were first identified in the producer
anns.postfix: species in the early 1970s, and they perform identical biochemical reactions to those seen in antibiotic resistant clinical strains (Walker and Walker, 1970; Benveniste and Davies, 1973), a direct correlation between synthesis of aminoglycosides and the presence of modification enzymes in producer Streptomyces is not always evident.

anns.prefix: Streptomycin resistance in the producer
anns.postfix: involves the function of the modification enzyme streptomycin 6-phosphotransferase that converts streptomycin to an inactive precursor streptomycin-6-phosphate.

anns.prefix: These enzymes are widespread among
anns.postfix: , and, together with similar enzymes found in pathogenic and non-pathogenic bacteria, they constitute the ‘β-lactamase superfamily’ of proteins (Sattler et al., 2015; Ogawara, 2016b).

anns.prefix: In a recent phylogenetic screen conducted by Ogawara, it was found that diverse β-lactamases belonging to classes A, B, and C exist in many
anns.postfix: species.

anns.prefix: This is due to the fact that most
anns.postfix: species produce β-lactamases constitutively, and their production is not related to resistance or synthesis of β-lactams.

anns.prefix: As discussed previously for AMEs,
anns.postfix: β-lactamases also exhibit diverse species-specific properties, again suggesting convergent evolution from different proteins to perform the same function, i.e., hydrolysis of the β-lactam ring (Allen et al., 2009).

anns.prefix: Perhaps these enzymes play alternative cellular functions in
anns.postfix: , are expressed at low levels, or are expressed in a growth phase different from biosynthesis?

anns.prefix: Overall, therefore, it has been proposed that β-lactamases may not play an important role in resistance in
anns.postfix: species, which may instead involve the function of low-affinity penicillin binding proteins (PBPs) (Ogawara, 2015) discussed in Section “Target Modification/Bypass/Protection Mechanisms” in this article.

anns.prefix: The best studied example of antibiotic efflux among producers is found in
anns.postfix: , which produces two closely related anticancer antibiotics, daunorubicin (Dnr) and doxorubicin (Dox).

anns.prefix: Efflux of these antibiotics in
anns.postfix: occurs by an ABC (ATP Binding Cassette) family transporter DrrAB coded by the drrAB genes embedded within the gene cluster responsible for biosynthesis of these antibiotics (Guilfoile and Hutchinson, 1991).

anns.prefix: Because of the location of the drrAB genes in the Dox biosynthesis gene cluster, this system is considered to be a dedicated transporter of Dnr and Dox in

anns.postfix: species, despite being Gram-positive, are highly resistant to penicillins, which is due to either overproduction of PBPs or synthesis of low-affinity PBPs (Ogawara, 2015).

anns.prefix: Other examples of producers containing several mechanisms for self-resistance include the following:
anns.postfix: contains both an efflux pump (MlbJYZ) and a sequestration protein (MlbQ) to protect against NAI-107 (Pozzi et al., 2016); S. rimosus has an ABC multi-drug efflux pump (OtrC) (Yu et al., 2012) and an MFS pump (OtrB) for efflux of oxytetracycline (Mak et al., 2014) along with OtrA to protect the ribosome by antibiotic removal (Doyle et al., 1991); S. fradiae contains several gene products (TlrA, TlrB, and TlrD) that modify the ribosome to prevent tylosin binding and uses TlrC for efflux (Mak et al., 2014); and S. chattanoogensis L10 contains several different efflux pumps for resistance against natamycin (Wang et al., 2017).

anns.prefix: In an interesting study, which tested 500
anns.postfix: strains enriched and isolated from soil against 21 antibiotics (including natural, semisynthetic, synthetic as well as recently introduced antibiotics), surprisingly all strains were multidrug resistant to 7 or 8 of the 21 tested antibiotics (D’Costa et al., 2006), suggesting widespread resistance mechanisms among modern organisms.
